Comment: This game is from a tourney from the Knights of Honor club here at gameknot (we're always looking for new members to the club so feel free to stop by and take a look at the club forum).  White begins with d3, known as the Mieses opening (I had to look that up as I've never seen that opening).
I go with my typical defense as Black, The Modern/Robatsch Defense.
Thus far, pretty typical moves for Black.
Thus far, pretty typical moves for Black.
Thus far, pretty typical moves for Black.
Thus far, pretty typical moves for Black.
As Black, in The Modern, I often go 4...a6 to set up b5 and queenside expansion.  However, when White strikes out early with c4, a6 doesn't make much sense.  Therefore, I mirror White.

I wanted the option to develop my N to either f6 or e7 and therefore moved 6...e6.

7.  Nge7--I think I was trying to reinforce control over f5, d5--particulary as it was possible that I'd move e5 to free up Bc8.
7.  Nge7--I think I was trying to reinforce control over f5, d5--particulary as it was possible that I'd move e5 to free up Bc8.
The question is put immediately to white.  If White had exchanged B for N, I would have attempted to open up the board to capitalize on the B-pair--perhaps d5.

White retreats.
Protecting h6.
Protecting h6.
Protecting h6.
11. Ne4.  I didn't understand the purpose behind this move.  It encouraged me to move f5, gaining space with tempo as the N only had 1 safe square--c3.
12...e5  I think with this move I was seeking to gain space on the King side.  It leaves a hole at d5 but Ne7 covered it and I had plans for Be6.

15.  Qa4  Looked to me that White had queenside designs (positional chess is not my strength but is something I'm working on).

I figured the Black Queen wasn't doing much on d8 and this could disrupt White's q-side designs.
I was unclear why 16. b3.  I certainly did not plan on taking b3 with my Queen.
I can't recall my exact reason for this except perhaps to line the Black rooks up on the f-file.
17. Nd5--I did not understand this move as it loses a pawn.

19. Qd4  This move initially concerned me as all I saw was White's Q and DSB bearing down on h6 and White's N ready to jump in and fork Black's K and R.  After a bit I was able to develop a plan.  (as an aside, in my post game review with Fritz, it recommended 19. Ng5+  hxg5 20. Bxd5  This would have changed the game quite a bit as Black would have had to move Rf7 to c7 to avoid being taken and to protect Nc6.)

(as an aside, in my post game review with Fritz, it recommended 19. Ng5+  hxg5 20. Bxd5  This would have changed the game quite a bit as Black would have had to move Rf7 to c7 to avoid being taken and to protect Nc6.)

20...Qd8 In hindsight, I came to believe that this was an error on Black's part.  My thought was to chase White's Q away or exchange Q's and try to get to an endgame with the pawn advantage.  However, I believe that 20...Nd4 would have been a better move.  When discussing this with my opponent (after move 20), he indicated had I gone 20...Nd4, he would have moved 21. Kf2, likely to avoid the potential fork.  From Nd4, Black could have exchanged the N for White's LSB, thereby eliminating White's B-pair.  As will be seen, Black had to give back his pawn advantage to break up that pair.

This Bishop does not move again and is a bone in Black's throat for the rest of the game.  Again, move 20...Nd4 and this is not a concern.
